Ordered mesoporous zirconium silicates as a catalyst for biofuel precursors synthesis Srinivasan Vinju Vasudevan Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Jin Cai Investigation Writing – review & editing Quan Bu Conceptualization Methodology Supervision Writing – review & editing Resources Project administration ⁎ Hanping Mao Resources Writing – review & editing Key Laboratory of Modern Agricultural Equipment and Technology, Ministry of Education, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang, Jiangsu 212013, China Key Laboratory of Modern Agricultural Equipment and Technology, Ministry of Education Jiangsu University Zhenjiang Jiangsu 212013 China Key Laboratory of Modern Agricultural Equipment and Technology, Ministry of Education, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang, Jiangsu 212013, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Zirconium incorporated three-dimensional ordered mesoporous silica (FDU-5) catalysts with different Si/Zr (100, 50 and 25) ratios were synthesized using an Evaporation Induced Self Assembly (EISA) method to maximize the incorporation of zirconium sites in the silica framework. The physicochemical properties of the synthesized materials were characterized by several techniques such as XRD, N2 sorption, diffuse reflectance UV–Vis, TEM, ammonia TPD, ICP-OES and pyridine adsorbed FT-IR. The catalytic activity was evaluated in acid-catalyzed esterification of glycerol with acetic acid. The effects of different reaction parameters were studied to optimize the maximum yields, such as reaction temperature, catalyst loading, acid/alcohol molar ratio, and reaction time. Esterification of glycerol with levulinic acid and levulinic acid with ethanol was also performed to synthesize fuel precursors. Reaction results showed that the prepared Zr-FDU-5(25) material was a very high catalytic activity, which depended mostly on the zirconium species' availability on the surfaces and framework. This zirconium containing FDU-5 material was very active in the esterification reaction and selective product formation at certain reaction conditions. The selected catalyst was recycled five times without significant loss in its activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords EISA Esterification Mesoporous silicates Zirconium Fuel additives 1 Introduction From the last decade, biofuels synthesis from renewable resources has been attractive as alternatives to fossil fuels due to their positive influence on the environment and petroleum-compatible products [1–4]. The biomass sources have huge potential to synthesize value-added chemicals by the pyrolysis, hydrolysis, liquefaction, and gasification reactions [5,6]. Further, these value-added chemicals can be used to produce direct fuels or fuel additives or fuel precursors through significant chemical reactions such as reduction, etherification, acetalization, aldol condensation, and esterification [7–10]. Even if the reduction reaction is better for producing direct biofuels, it has restrictions on creating long-chain hydrocarbon fuels from biomass-derived molecules. Therefore, importance has been given to aldol condensation, acetalization, esterification, and etherification reactions to produce long-chain oxygenated compounds with acid or base catalyst aid to prepare biofuel precursors. Among, esterification is an important and good choice for producing biofuels precursor synthesis. Esterification reaction could produce long-chain (C12 C20) organic compounds, which are particularly useful for decreasing bio-oil acidity, biofuel synthesis, and enhancing the heating value of liquid fuel [11–13]. An increased biodiesel production and biomass conversion reactions are producing glycerol, levulinic acid and other important chemical accumulation. In order to deal with the excess amount of glycerol, researchers have focused on developing new approaches to transform glycerol into value products. Esterification of glycerol with acetic acid is one of the simple and best ways of glycerol utilization. The esterified products of glycerol such as monoacetin (AA) and diacetin (DA) are used in cryogenics and biodegradable polyesters productions, while another important triacetin (TA) product used as cosmetics and fuel additives [14–16]. In this sequence, another biomass-derived molecule, Levulinic acid, is considered one of the most important chemicals due to its potential as a versatile building block to synthesize valuable fuels and chemicals. The esterified products of levulinic acid can be utilized in many applications such as flavoring agents, fuel additives, solvents, plasticizers, fragrances, and biodiesel as blending components, thus potentially replacing a significant amount of petroleum-derived chemical feedstock [17–20]. Traditionally, strong mineral acids promote the esterification processes, including HCl and H2SO4, and other strong acidic systems. However, the non-recoverability, corrosiveness, toxic nature and environmental concern of the homogeneous catalysts make it unfair in practical application. These shortcomings could be addressed using heterogeneous solid acid catalysts, which are the best substitutes for homogeneous catalysts due to their easy recovery, separation of products, use for more reaction runs and reducing environmental effects [21]. As a solid acid catalytic support, mesoporous silica materials have been developed enormously since the discovery of MCM-41. They have attracted much attention in catalysis, energy storage, and multidisciplinary fields due to their relatively high surface area, large pores, and diffusion limitations compared with zeolite materials [22–25]. In mesoporous series, the three-dimensional (3D) mesoporous silica materials such as KIT-6, KIT-5, MCM-48, SBA-16 and TUD-1 significantly improve many catalytic reactions compared to conventional 1D and 2D mesoporous SBA-15 and MCM-41 [26–28]. Moreover, the 3D mesoporous silica materials have advantages like being more resistant to pore blocking, good mass transfer of the reactant molecules in the pore channels, and providing more active and adsorption sites. These properties are making more interest in it to use as a support in catalysis. Besides, the 3D mesoporous silica materials play an important role in biomass conversion reactions. For example, Nandiwale et al. studied lignin depolymerization using Zr-KIT-5 as a catalyst and reported that the catalytic activity was good and restricted more coke formation than the H-ZSM-5 catalyst [29]. Nagu et al. compared the Ni-supported SBA-15 (2D-hexagonal) and SBA-16 (3D-cubic) silica materials as catalysts for reducing biomass-derived phenol to cyclohexanol in gas-phase conditions. They were found that the Ni-supported SBA-16 had remarkable activity more than SBA-15 due to the 3D cubic structure of SBA-16, which helped to uniform distribution Ni nanoparticles [30]. The sulfonic acid functionalized or metal incorporated KIT-6 was reported for fructose to synthesize bio-platform molecule 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) with good yield [31]. The bimetallic Pa-Ni supported on 3D disordered mesoporous silica TUD-1 was reported for furfural to important bio-product synthesis, and that was had good catalytic activity due to uniform distribution of bimetals and interaction on the support [32]. The Sn-TUD-1 catalyst performance was good in the synthesis of different alkyl levulinate due to the interconnected 3D structure was facilitated the more accommodation of metal ions [19]. Recently, Hu et al. reported that the sulfonated FDU-5, SBA-16 and SBA-15 for xylose to furfural conversion among the FDU-5 supported catalyst was outperformed because of the acidity and structural morphology of the catalyst [33]. The recently developed mesoporous FDU-5 silica is a 3D bicontinuous (Ia3d) mesostructured with high surface area, tunable pores sizes, and more advantages than conventional mesoporous materials. These properties make FDU-5 good support and better accessibility for substrates and products, which is not much studied as support in catalysis [34,35]. Moreover, it can be synthesized in mildly acidic conditions using the Evaporation Induced Self-assembly method via one-pot synthesis. FDU-5 mesoporous silica can be tuned to catalytically active ones with the impregnation or incorporation of transition metals. Previously, iron and manganese metal ions were incorporated in the FDU-5 silica framework and reported as an efficient catalyst for Friedel craft benzylation of benzene and epoxidation of trans-stilbene [13,36]. In this series, zirconium is an interesting metal to incorporate in mesoporous silica, creating a more Lewis acidic center and Brønsted acidic sites in a mesoporous silica framework depending on synthetic conditions. These acidic sites have been very active in catalysis, including dehydration [37,38], hydrolyses, hydrogenation [39], CC bond formation reactions [40,41] and biomass conversion reactions [42]. However, few reports are only on zirconium modified three-dimensional mesoporous silica materials for bio-based fuels and products via esterification. This work presented a single-step synthesis method of Zr-incorporated mesoporous FDU-5 (three-dimensional mesoporous silica) for catalytic application of fuel additives synthesis. The EISA method was allowed to incorporate the maximum zirconium in the FDU-5 to avoid the loss of metal ions during synthesis. The glycerol esterification with acetic acid, glycerol esterification with levulinic acid, and levulinic acid esterification with ethanol was performed with Zr-FDU-5 catalyst. The catalytic performance of the synthesized catalyst in the esterification reaction has proven to be an excellent acid catalyst because of the highly accessible catalytic sites and the mesoporous structure. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The Pluronic P123 (poly (ethylene oxide)-poly(propylene oxide)-poly (ethylene oxide)) (EO20-PO70-EO20), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS 98%), Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2•8H2O), (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxy silane(3-MPTS) and hydrochloric acid (HCl 35%) were of analytical reagent grade and purchased from Sigma Aldrich company. Levulinic acid, acetic acid (glacial) and glycerol were purchased from Merck company. All the chemicals used in the experiments were analytical-grade and used without further purification. Deionized water was obtained from an analytical laboratory. 2.2 Synthesis procedure of Zr-FDU-5 The FDU-5 synthesis was carried out using TEOS with Pluronic P123 as the silica source and structure-directing agent. In a typical synthesis, 2 g of P123 was dissolved in 40 g of ethanol followed by 0.2 g HCl solution (2.5 M) and 1.8 g of deionized H2O. The solution mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h; subsequently, a 0.230 g of 3-MPTS was added and stirred for another 2 h. Then, 4.16 g of TEOS and a necessary amount of ZrOCl2•8H2O were added. Finally, the whole solution was stirred for 6 h and the resulting clear solution was transferred into a petridis, dried in air for 2 days, and turned into a solid product. The as-synthesized products were heated in a furnace at 550 °C for 5 h at the rate of 1 °C/min to get the template-free materials. The obtained materials were designated as Zr-FDU-5(x), where x is the ratio of 100, 50 and 25. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Rigaku instrument in the 2θ value range of 0.5–6 and 10–80 ° with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at a resolution of 0.02°. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K using a Quantachrome porosimeter (Quantosorb SI). The pore size distributions were calculated from the analysis of the isotherm's adsorption points using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) algorithm and the pore volume was measured at P/Po = 0.99 single points. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis) profiles were recorded in the range of 200 to 800 nm by a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer with BaSO4 as reference. For TPD analysis, 0.05 g catalyst was placed in a U-shaped quartz tube between glass wools, heated with a flow of He gas at the rate of 80 mL/min with a heating rate of 15 °C/min up to 250 °C and kept at this temperature for 2 h. Then it was cooled to room temperature using He gas at the same flow rate. Finally, the NH3-TPD was run from 100 to 600 °C at a heating rate of 15 °C/min with He flow at 60 mL/min. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis was taken on a Nicolet iS5 instrument with the 2 cm−1 resolution. The synthesized samples were ground with KBr, followed by pressing into pellets for IR and measured in the range of 4000–600 cm−1. For pyridine FT-IR, 100 mg of each prepared catalyst was dried at 250 °C for 3 h to remove the adsorbed species. Then the samples were wetted and equilibrated with pyridine for 12 h. All the samples were then heated at 100 °C for 0.5 h at atmospheric pressure to remove the physisorbed pyridine and FTIR analysis was carried out in the Nicolet iS5 instrument in absorbance mode. Further, High-Resolution Scanning Electron Microscope (HR-TEM) was used to characterize the morphology and porosity of the samples using JEOL JEM 2100 with an accelerating voltage of 200 keV. Chemical compositions were investigated by an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on a Perkin Elmer OES Optima 5300 DV spectrometer. 2.4 Catalytic activity for biofuel precursors synthesis using Zr-FDU-5 All the prepared catalysts were tested for esterification of glycerol with acetic acid and levulinic acid. In a typical reaction, 0.92 g of glycerol (0.01 mol) and 5.4 g (0.09 mol) acetic acid were added to a 100 mL two-necked round bottom with an air condenser and stirred well to mix both reactants. Then a Dean-Stark apparatus was attached to remove water from the reaction mixture, and 50 mg of the Zr-FDU-5 catalyst was added to the reaction mixture. Before adding the catalyst into the reaction mixture that was pre-activated. A 50 mg of catalyst was taken in a silica crucible for pre-activation and kept in a furnace at 250 °C for 3 h at a heating rate of 5 °C/min and cooled to room temperature. The 1:9 molar ratio was preferred due to getting more triacetate product formation. The reaction of the temperature was studied between 90 and 130 °C. Samples were withdrawn at regular intervals, centrifuged, and analyzed in a Shimadzu GC-17A equipped with RTX-5 a capillary column (internal diameter: 0.25 mm, length: 30 m) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) using nitrogen as a carrier gas and air for the detector function (total flow of 1.3 mL/min) and the products were also confirmed by GC–MS (Agilent Technologies 7890A). In GC–MS analysis, GC program temperature was set from 40 °C for 5 min then increased up to 250 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. The total column flow was 1.2 mL/min, where helium was used as the carrier gas. The MS detector was operated in the electron ionization mode (70 eV) with an ionization temperature of 230 °C. The identification of individual compounds was performed by comparing experimental mass spectra with those in the NIST Mass Spectral library. The conversions were based on the consumed glycerol in the reaction mixture. After completing the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and washed severely with distilled water and methanol to remove organic impurities. Then it was dried in the oven at 120 °C for 3 h and reused in consecutive acetylation reaction cycles adopting the same regeneration method for each reuse. Leaching of the active sites (Zr) after reusability studies were determined using ICP-OES analysis. Esterification of glycerol with levulinic acid: The above procedure was used with the 1:9 molar ratio of glycerol to levulinic acid using 50 mg of Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst at 130 °C. The above procedures were followed to analyze the reaction results. Esterification of levulinic acid with ethanol: The esterification reaction of levulinic acid with ethanol was performed in a 50 mL two-necked round bottom flask with a reflux condenser. Coldwater circulation was maintained to avoid the escape of ethanol from the reaction mixture. The reaction conditions were 50 mg of Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst, 130 °C, 1:9 molar ratio of levulinic acid to ethanol. After completing the reaction, the mixture was cooled, and the solid catalyst was filtered and analyzed in GC and GC–MS with the same method of glycerol esterification reaction. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Physico-chemical properties of synthesized catalysts The low and high angle X-ray diffraction patterns of Zr-FDU-5 with different Si/Zr ratios are shown in Fig. 1. In low angle XRD, all the prepared samples were exhibited a high-intensity diffraction peak at 1.2 2θ indexed to the (211) plane followed by a small peak at around 1.26 −1.3 2θ indexed to the (200) plane, suggesting the formation of the typical Ia3d bicontinuous cubic mesoporous framework with high order [13,35]. A prominent decrease was noted in the intensity of (211) plane at higher Zr content; meanwhile, the unit cell parameters were increased in all the Zr incorporated FDU-5 than pure silica FDU-5 and a slight marginal shift was observed towards lower angles in XRD, indicating an appreciable amount of metal ions were assimilated in the silica material. The wide-angle XRD patterns of Zr-FDU-5 samples were compared and shown in Fig. 1(b). All the samples were displayed a broad peak in the 2θ range of 15–30, which attributes the amorphous nature of SiO2. There were no characteristic reflection peaks in the XRD for ZrO2 in all Zr-FUD-5 samples, which was evident in the absence of bulk ZrO2 particles in these samples. N2 sorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distributions were determined from the adsorption points and the results are shown in Fig. 2 (a and b). All samples represent type IV with H2 hysteresis loop, an obvious characteristic of mesoporous materials [13]. The sharp steps of capillary condensation of N2 were observed at a relative pressure (P/P0= 0.4–0.65) in all the isotherms of FDU-5, indicating that these samples possess uniform pore size. ICP-OES analysis was used to measure the elemental content of the Zr-FDU-5 samples, and their compositions are listed in Table 1 . The ICP-OES analysis is confirmed that the silicons to zirconium ratios of Zr-FDU-5 samples were in close agreement with those in the synthesis mixture. The FT-IR spectra of Si-FDU-5 and Zr-FDU-5 with various Si/Zr ratios are shown in Fig. 3. A band at 1640 cm−1 was attributed to the bending vibration of OH of the hydroxyl groups, which belongs to the adsorbed water molecules on the surface of the catalysts. The band at 809 and 1088 cm−1 corresponded to the symmetric stretching and asymmetric stretching mode of Si-O-Si. In pure silica FDU-5, a slight band around 970 cm−1 was assigned to the vibration of Si-OH, which intense was increased as the loading of Zr increased, indicating the bond formations of Si-O-Zr in the mesoporous framework [43]. The FT-IR results are suggested that the Zr atoms were incorporated and coordinated with surface silanol in the mesoporous silica framework. The diffuse reflectance UV–Vis spectra were analyzed for both the calcinated and as-synthesized samples (before calcination) to authenticate the incorporation of Zr4+ in the mesoporous silica framework of FDU-5 material and the spectra are shown in Fig. 4a and 4b. An absorption band around 207 nm was observed in all the calcined Zr-FDU-5 catalysts ascribed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) from an O2 to an isolated Zr4+ ion. An absorption band at 235 nm has appeared in the as-synthesized catalysts attributed to LMCT of O2 to Zr4+ typically present in ZrO2 or Zr(IV) silicate, and the same band has disappeared after calcination. Based on these observations, we accomplish that most Zr ions were incorporated as a Zr4+ ion in a tetrahedral configuration in the final Zr-FDU-5 materials. The band at 260 nm samples may be attributed to the presence of homogeneously distributed ZrO2 nanoparticles [44,45]. The total surface acidity of the Zr-FDU-5 catalysts was measured by NH3-TPD analysis (Fig. 5), and the surface acidities are displayed in Table 1. In the NH3-TPD profile, two peaks were appeared around 125–150 °C and at 250 to 400 °C, which indicated the formation of weak acidic and moderate acidic sites, respectively. Generally, strong acidic sites are forming beyond 450 °C, which was observed in Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst, but the peak was ended with an increased way; it might be that the higher zirconium amounts created strong acidic sites [46]. Further, the surface acidic sites of the Zr-FDU-5 catalysts were studied by pyridine adsorption. The pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra were displayed four absorption bands at 1446, 1492, 1544, and 1600 cm−1 (Fig. 5b). The absorption bands at 1446 and 1600 cm−1 ascribed to pyridine molecules coordinated to Lewis acid sites arising from the incorporation of Zr into the silica framework. A combination of Lewis and Brønsted sites was associated with the band at 1492 cm−1, and the absorption band at 1544 cm−1 characterized the presence of Brønsted acidic sites. The Brønsted acidic sites were increased when increasing the Zr contents, which could be seen from the spectra. Probably zirconium incorporated silica catalyst will induce Lewis acidic sites [44,45]. However, there were Brønsted acidic sites found in Zr-FUD-5 materials due to the synthesis method of catalyst (EISA method), which led to forming more hydroxyl groups of Zr-OH on the surface [47]. Further, to confirm the material's porous nature, the TEM analyses were taken and exhibited the formation of the well-arranged mesoporous structures. Even at a higher amount of zirconium, the mesoporous structure did not collapse (Fig. 6). Further, the elemental mapping of the FIB-SEM image of Zr-FDU-5(25) confirmed the homogeneous distribution of Zr species in the synthesized materials. The Zr content observed by EDX was 5.22 wt% (Fig. 7), which is in close agreement with the ICP-OES result. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Zr-FDU-5 catalysts The acidic activities of the synthesized zirconium modified FDU-5 catalysts with 100, 50, and 25 of Si/Zr ratio were evaluated in glycerol esterification with acetic acid (Scheme 1 ). Initially, all the catalysts were tested to a 1:3 ratio of glycerol to acetic acid at 90 °C for 6 h, and the obtained results are displayed in Fig. 8(a–c). At this condition, the Zr-FUD-5(25) catalyst showed a 72% conversion of glycerol with 12% selectivity of TA. The other solid acids Zr-FDU-5(100) and Zr-FDU-(50) did not form any TA and converted 45% and 60% glycerol, respectively. The selectivity of MA, DA, and TA were varied according to the acidity of the catalyst and the reaction conditions. The glycerol conversion was increased with an increase in Si/Zr ratio, and the product selectivities were also increased. It implies that the higher amount of zirconium contents were induced more acidic sites or acidic density in the Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst that can be observed from the result of NH3-TPD (Table 1). It is confirmed that the acidic strength promotes the formation of TA products. An experiment was performed without catalyst at the above-said reaction conditions, which resulted in 45 MA and 8% DA with the 20% conversion of glycerol. It indicates that the role of the catalyst is important to form the DA and TA products. Reaction conditions: Catalyst amount - 50 mg, Solventless, Temp. - 90 °C, Time −6 h Generally, glycerol esterification is an equilibrium reaction, which needs more acetic acid to form other selective products of DA and TA from glycerol. Further, the various glycerol to acetic acid ratios 1:6 and 1:9 was executed for all the catalysts at 90 °C for 6 h (shown in Fig.8b and Fig. 8c, respectively). It was noted that the increased molar concentration of acetic acid influenced the product distribution as well marginal effect brought in glycerol conversion. There was no TA formation for the Zr-FDU-5(100) ratio even at the increase of acetic acid ratios while the MA selectivity decreased and DA selectivity improved. The same trend can be observed for other Zr-FUD-5(50) and Zr-FDU-5(25) catalysts. The TA selectivity was especially obtained 12 to 20% when increasing the acetic acid molar ratio for the Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst. It might be the reason for higher acidic strength and increased amounts of Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites of the Zr-FUD-5(25) catalyst. Reaction conditions: Catalyst amount - 50 mg, Solventless After optimizing the molar ratio of glycerol to acetic acid and zirconium-containing catalyst ratios at 90 °C, the active catalyst Zr-FDU-5(25) was chosen to study the influences of different temperatures at a varied time interval. The results are shown in Fig. 9. The MA selectivity was 90% in 2 h duration for Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst at 90 °C (Fig. 9a). It was reduced to 28% after 10 h while the other selective products DA and TA were increased to 64% and 28%, respectively at 90 °C. When increasing the temperature from 110 °C to 130 °C (Fig. 9b and Fig. 9c respectively), the DA selectivity increased and the formation of TA also increased until 8 h, but the conversion of glycerol was almost the same. The TA formed as 35% and 72% selectively when extending the time to 10 h, at 110 °C and 130 °C, respectively. The highest TA selectivity and conversion of glycerol (98% at 130 °C for 10 h) was achieved when increasing the time and temperature. The results revealed that glycerol esterification with acetic acid is time and temperature dependent as well the acidic strength of the catalyst. The same reaction without catalyst at 130 °C with 1:9 molar ratio of glycerol to acetic acid was performed for 10 h. It resulted in a 58% conversion of glycerol with the selectivity of 68 MA and 32% DA. There was no formation of TA product selectivity. It confirms that the active catalytic sites are needed to convert the MA and DA to the TA products during catalysis. Further, the reports on Zr-based heterogeneous catalysts for the esterification of glycerol with acetic acid were compared and the comparisons are displayed in Table 2 . All the catalysts led to a significant change in the conversion of glycerol and selectivity of the products according to their active sites, acidity and operating conditions. The other esterification of glycerol with levulinic acid was performed in this sequence by the Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst (Scheme 2 ). The reaction results are shown in Table 3 . Previously, Camino et al. evaluated Zr-SBA-16(25) as a catalyst for synthesizing esterified glycerol compounds with levulinic acid. They were reported 62 and 37% yield of di and tri esterified compounds respectively at 140 °C with 15 h duration. Similarly, in this work, we performed the esterification of glycerol with levulinic acid reaction with an optimized reaction condition of glycerol esterification with acetic acid (130 °C, 1: 9 molar ratio of reactant) in a different time interval. The glycerol conversion was 18% at initial hours with 90 and 10% selectivity of mono and di derivative compounds. As time increased, the conversion and selective products were also increased. After 10 h, the glycerol conversion was 90% with the selectivity of 15%, 45% and 40% of mono, di and tri esterified compounds of levulinic acid, respectively. These results were almost the same as reported by Gonzalez-Arellano et al. but differ in product selectivity [18]; it might be the reason for differences in reaction conditions and the synthesis method of catalyst. However, we observed the full conversion of glycerol and marginal effect in selective products with the extent of reaction time to 24 h. The reaction was also performed without a catalyst and gave the 52% of glycerol conversion and appreciable selective products due to levulinic acid's self-acidic strength. The microporous zeolite (Si/Al = 15, commercially purchased, 2.1 mmol/g of acidity) was tested in glycerol esterification with levulinic acid; it converted the glycerol 100%, but the tri esterified products were less (17%) compared with Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst at the similar catalytic condition. The strong acidity of zeolite might lead to high adsorption of reactants or products. It implied that the porosity is also a matter in selective product conversion and the other parameters like the reactant's molar ratio, time, and temperature. Esterification of levulinic acid with ethanol is an important reaction (Scheme 3 ) to synthesize fuel additive, plasticizing agent, solvent. The most active Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst was studied for ethyl levulinate synthesis with a time effect at 130 °C, 1:9 molar ratio of levulinic acid and ethanol, and the results are presented in Table 3. The conversion of levulinic acid was 28% and 50% for 2 and 4 h, respectively and the selectivity was 100%. From the results, we have observed that the conversion increased as time increased, but the selectivity was reduced due to the other product formations. After 10 h, the levulinic acid conversion was 98% with the selectivity of 90%; then, the full conversion of levulinic acid was achieved with the reaction duration of 24 h while the selectivity was reduced to 82%. When performing the reaction without catalyst, the conversion was only 12% with no product selectivity. Further, the results of esterification of levulinic acid with ethanol have been compared with the reported Zr-based catalyst (Table 4 ). Recently, Shestakova et al. reported Zr substituted polyoxometalate grafted on mesoporous MCM-41 silica for esterification of levulinic acid with ethanol. It resulted in a 69.2% ethyl levulinate yield due to the synergistic effect of Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites of the Zr and polyoxometalate (Table 4, entry 8). Ramli et al. investigated different heteropoly acid loaded ZrO2 for ethyl levulinate production, resulting in 97.3% yield (Table 4, entry 9). Another interesting report is Zr-based metal organic framework UiO-66-(COOH)2, which gave 97% of ethyl levulinate yield at a lower temperature due to the interplay of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites of Zr and –COOH group respectively (Table 4, entry 10). The sulfated Si-doped ZrO2 (Table4, entry 11) and SO4 2−/ZrO2 loaded membrane catalyst (Table 4, entry 12) were performed well in the esterification of levulinic acid with ethanol. All the results showed that the Zr-based catalysts were effectively played a role in the levulinic acid conversion and selective product formation by the Lewis and Brønsted acid combination. Generally, both the Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites are active in all the esterification reactions, which may occur in both Lewis and Brønsted acid site mechanisms. The Lewis acidic sites first activate the carbonyl group of the reactant, which will form an electrophilic center on the carbonyl carbon atom of the reactant then interact with the hydroxyl group of other reactants. In another way, the Brønsted acid sites first may activate the carbonyl group of the reactant by protonation, which will interact with the hydroxyl group of the other reactants. Finally, both way leads to dehydration to form the desired products [14,55]. The environmental sustainability and economics of the catalytic process depend on the possibility of reusing the catalyst. In this sense, the heterogeneous nature of the Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst was investigated by performing reusability in glycerol esterification reaction with acetic acid. The recyclability reaction was performed with a 1:9 molar ratio of glycerol to acetic acid, 50 mg of catalyst at 130 °C for 4 h. The Zr-FDU-5(25) catalyst was recovered after every run and thoroughly washed with methanol and ethyl acetate, dried in an oven at 100 °C for 2 h and tested for the next four cycles (Fig. 10 ). A gradual decrease in activity was noticed in each cycle, which might be loss of catalyst in every cycle (∼x223C 1 to 2 mg) and blocked pores by the unreacted molecules. In the fifth cycle, the catalyst was heated at 550 °C for 5 h in an air atmosphere and used in the reaction. We observed a negligible loss of its catalytic activity compared with its fresh catalytic activity. Finally, the recycled catalyst was analyzed with ICP-OES to know the zirconium content, which showed a 4.8% zirconium presence. It was 0.3% less than fresh catalyst and negligible. These results confirmed the stability of Zr4+ in support and the heterogeneous nature of the catalyst. Reaction conditions: Glycerol: acetic acid - 1:9 mmol, time – 4 h, temperature – 130 °C, 50 mg catalyst. 4 Conclusion Zirconium incorporated 3D ordered mesoporous silicates (FDU-5) were successfully prepared by the EISA method. The ICP-OES and elemental mapping results confirmed the presence of maximum zirconium species as in experimental synthesis. The BET analysis showed the specific surface area in the range of 514–435 m2/g. TEM analysis confirmed that the porosity and ordered structure of the catalyst remained unchanged after incorporating zirconium ions into the silica framework. DRS-UV–Vis confirmed most of the Zr4+ presence in tetrahedral coordination. The catalytic activity was well in glycerol esterification with acetic acid, esterification with levulinic acid and levulinic acid esterification with ethanol due to the presence of Brønsted and Lewis dual acidic sites in Zr-FDU-5. The important fuel additive triacetin (TA) was obtained 72% selectivity with 98% conversion of glycerol at 130 °C for 10 h with 1:9 glycerol to acetic acid ratio. In the same reaction condition, 90% of ethyl levulinate was obtained with 98% conversion of levulinic acid. The results conclude that the esterification reaction depends on catalyst acidity, time, temperature, and reactant molar ratio. Overall, the Zr incorporated FDU-5 3D silica materials are active, cost-effective, stable, reusable catalysts. The 3D porous nature of FDU-5 makes it a good catalytically support and reactive material; it would be a good support to incorporate other kinds of transition metals. coredata.dc:description: Zirconium incorporated three-dimensional ordered mesoporous silica (FDU-5) catalysts with different Si/Zr (100, 50 and 25) ratios were synthesized using an Evaporation Induced Self Assembly (EISA) method to maximize the incorporation of zirconium sites in the silica framework. The physicochemical properties of the synthesized materials were characterized by several techniques such as XRD, N2 sorption, diffuse reflectance UV–Vis, TEM, ammonia TPD, ICP-OES and pyridine adsorbed FT-IR. The catalytic activity was evaluated in acid-catalyzed esterification of glycerol with acetic acid. The effects of different reaction parameters were studied to optimize the maximum yields, such as reaction temperature, catalyst loading, acid/alcohol molar ratio, and reaction time. Esterification of glycerol with levulinic acid and levulinic acid with ethanol was also performed to synthesize fuel precursors. Reaction results showed that the prepared Zr-FDU-5(25) material was a very high catalytic activity, which depended mostly on the zirconium species' availability on the surfaces and framework. This zirconium containing FDU-5 material was very active in the esterification reaction and selective product formation at certain reaction conditions. The selected catalyst was recycled five times without significant loss in its activity.
coredata.dc:title: Ordered mesoporous zirconium silicates as a catalyst for biofuel precursors synthesis
